docs.text: Rafalinux Personal Website Hi, my name is Rafa Rafalinux is only a nickname, but Rafa is a too common name for be used in a landing page. He is a clinical researcher, and also a physician and a college professor. When not at work, you can find him cooking or reading comics. And sometimes he codes.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Rafalinux is only a nickname, but Rafa is a too common name for be used in a landing page. He is a clinical researcher, and also a physician and a college professor. When not at work, you can find him cooking or reading comics. And sometimes he codes.
docs.title: Hi, my name is Rafa

docs.text: Rafa's profile He is a clinical researcher , and also a physician and a college professor . When he is not at work, you can find him cooking or reading comics. And sometimes he codes. Rafa completed his university education with a Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery in 2001 from the Complutense University of Madrid. He obtained a specialization in Internal Medicine between 2002 and 2007. Since 2007, he has been working as a physician at the University Hospital of Móstoles From a research perspective, he has co-authored several articles academic journals (see his ORCID profile ). His academic interest is focused on vascular risk factors such as arterial hypertension, metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and on machine learning . He obtained a Ph.D. in artificial intelligence applied to medicine in 2020. He also has developed several web applications using the client-server model as the front-end for these databases. He has intermediate-level knowledge of Python, PHP, R, and BASH. And he loves Debian/Linux .
docs.title: About

docs.text: He is a clinical researcher , and also a physician and a college professor . When he is not at work, you can find him cooking or reading comics. And sometimes he codes. Rafa completed his university education with a Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery in 2001 from the Complutense University of Madrid. He obtained a specialization in Internal Medicine between 2002 and 2007. Since 2007, he has been working as a physician at the University Hospital of Móstoles From a research perspective, he has co-authored several articles academic journals (see his ORCID profile ). His academic interest is focused on vascular risk factors such as arterial hypertension, metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and on machine learning . He obtained a Ph.D. in artificial intelligence applied to medicine in 2020. He also has developed several web applications using the client-server model as the front-end for these databases. He has intermediate-level knowledge of Python, PHP, R, and BASH. And he loves Debian/Linux .

docs.text: Useful code chunks Sometimes I'm tired of searching for tips and tricks on Linux, PHP, R, Python, Latex, or Markdown. I will try to write down some useful tricks to make my life easier. Mkdocs This site has been built using mkdocs.org ., sofor full documentation visit mkdocs.org . Some useful tips and reference material can be found at Material for MkDocs , such as how to add tables, images, formatting, and so on. A starting guide can be found here . Useful commands I usually build my local site in my hard drive, and later commit changes using GitHub. mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project. mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server. mkdocs build - Build the documentation site. mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit. How to write pages MkDocs is very easy. It uses markdown . Here can be found a guide to write the documentation in MkDocs. How to deploy the site To deploy the entire site using GitHub Pages, please visit Deploying your docs Project layout By creating a new project, the configuration will be as follows: mkdocs.yml # The configuration file. docs/ index.md # The documentation homepage. ... # Other markdown pages, images and other files. Custom themes Themes can be chosen from built-in themes , or from third-party sites. There are some cool themes to customize MkDocs in GitHub .
docs.title: Coding stuff

docs.text: College stuff I recenttly discovered GitHub, not only as a code repository, but as a file repository as well. I uploaded some lectures of the topic I teach. Students will have access to PDF files, both text and slides.
